subject: Correct versions in the URLs
commit_message:
Correct versions in the URLs

The Keystone Endpoints setup by Devstack and all of the other
installers have been appending the versions on to the URLs for
Keystone.  This binds an Open Stack deployment to a specific version of
the identity API, even if the Keystone server itself supports multiple
versions.

Merely removing the version string, however, does not fix the problem,
as the URL in the endpoint is not by itself usable.  If there is no
version appended, the client attempts to use the URL as is, and appends
on the suburl for the desired resource.  For example, if the endpoint
is https://hostname:35357  and the client is attempting to use the
v2 API to access users, it will generate the url
https://hostname:35357/user  which will fail.  It needs to generate
the URL:  https://hostname:35357/v3/user according to the identity
specification.

This change does two things.
1) At the base level, it removes any version strings from the
Management URL.
2) At the API specific level, it appends the appropriate version string
onto the URL before attempting to compose the suburls.

Discovery could potentially perform the second step.  Assuming that all
URLs were non-version specific, the client could make a call to the
endpoint to discover which version of the API is supported.
However, this does not make sense for three reasons:

1.  Discovery was performed already when the client was created.  The
client already knows which versions are supported.
2.  It is an additional roundtrip that would have to be made for every
call to the server.
3.  We already require a-priori knowledge to compose the URLs.  This
would perform a minimal additional server driven configuration, while
still failing to adequetly apply the principals of REST.

Regardless of the above, these changes are required in order to allow
access to the V3 API to deployemnt that currently have older clients
accessing the V2.0 APIs.

Blueprint: endpoint-versioning

Change-Id: I4ae0d9e250feb3f2974284645907ceaa50e9caf0

subject: User a more accurate max_delay for reconnects
commit_message:
User a more accurate max_delay for reconnects

In an HA deployment, a 60 seconds delay between reconnects can be quite
problematic. This patch changes the delay calculation by setting the max
delay to 5s and by changing the way it is increased.

Unfortunately, this is one of the places where both our main drivers are
not consistent. Rabbit's driver uses configuration parameters for this
whereas qpid's driver has never had one. However, I would prefer not
adding configuration paremeters to qpid's driver for the following
reasons:

    1. Most of OpenStack services depend on the messaging layer, hence
    they need it to be available. A 5s delay seems to be reasonable and
    I could argue the need of tune it further. Although so frequent
    reconnects can add load to the network, that wouldn't be the main
    issue if one of the brokers go down.
    2. We're trying to move away from configuration options towards using
    transport URL. This path is still not clear and I would
    prefer avoiding adding new options until we clear it out.

subject: NodeLocked returns 503 error status
commit_message:
NodeLocked returns 503 error status

The NodeLocked exception status code was incorrectly set to 409
CONFLICT.  That status is (correctly) used by client-side errors, such
as MACAlreadyExists and InvalidState, which belong in the 4xx class of
HTTP error codes.

Instead, NodeLocked is a temporary server-side error and as such should
use the 503 error code, indicating that the client should re-issue the
request unchanged after waiting for the resource state to change on the
server side.

subject: Use 0-based indices for location entries
commit_message:
Use 0-based indices for location entries

Glance server currently uses 1-based indices for indexing location
entries. This violates the JSON-pointer RFC (RFC 6901) which states that
indicies should be 0-based. Furthermore, since this deviation is not
mentioned in the docs any application directly calling the REST APIs
would trip over it.

This commit makes Glance use zero-based indexing for location entries.

Note that the "show_multiple_locations" config option should be set to
True to expose location related REST operations.

DocImpact: Since this change modifies user-visible Glance behaviour it
should be explicitly documented because the previous behaviour (1-based
indexing), though not explicitly documented, was exposed through the
REST APIs.

subject: Add ability to modify volume type
commit_message:
Add ability to modify volume type

This patch adds the volume retype operation, which allows a user to
change a given volume's type.

When retyping, the scheduler checks if the volume's current host can
accept the new type (i.e., it checks if the host passes the filters when
using the new type). If the current host is suitable, its manager is
called which calls upon the driver to change the volume's type.

There are two cases where a retype operation may require migrating the
volume:
1. The volume's current host cannot accept the new type
2. The volume's driver cannot perform the retype operation

In case of a migration, a volume with the new type is created, and the
data is migrated to it.

Volume migrations resulting from retype can be controlled by passing a
policy, which can be either:
1. 'never': Never migrate (the retype fails if migration is required)
   (default)
2. 'on-demand': Migrate when necessary

This version will cause retype operations to fail if the current and
new volume types have different:
1. QoS settings that are enforced by the front-end for in-use volumes.
2. encryption settings.

Subsequent patches can address these cases.

DocImpact

Change-Id: I2dc99b4fa64d611d2bb936fc3890ca334e08bb55
Implements: blueprint volume-retype

subject: Simplify locking around acquiring Node resources
commit_message:
Simplify locking around acquiring Node resources

task_manager.TaskManager and resource_manager.NodeManager were both
locking resources, but in different ways.

TaskManager used a DB-backed lock to guarantee cross-host exclusivity of
non-shared locks, even in the face of a conductor going offline.

NodeManager used lockutils.synchronized to guard creation of
instances of itself. For each node id, this class acted like a
singleton. Additionally, it kept references back to each TaskManager
which had acquired either shared or exlusive access to that Node. This
back-reference (and the related garbage collection) was not necessary
because most access was done within an exclusive lock context, and
therefor the benefit of resource caching was never realized.

This patch replaces NodeManager with a simple NodeResource class.  It is
now just a container to store and easily access objects associated with
a node, namely the node's port(s) and the node's driver object.

This patch also moves the driver loading out from NodeManager and into
TaskManager. As a result of this, significant refactoring of the unit
tests had to be done to mock the extension loading in a different way.

This patch updates the unit tests and module documentation accordingly.

Change-Id: Ic6fc1e198cd4979d3c4746db821ae959f42f4678

subject: Fixes Hyper-V VHDX snapshot bigger than instance
commit_message:
Fixes Hyper-V VHDX snapshot bigger than instance

In Hyper-V, the deployed images will be extended having their
metadata size added to their base image size. This may lead to
snapshots bigger than the flavor size.

This patch adds support to the V2 utils module, so that the
maximum internal size of a requested image may be calculated
in a similar way it is done in the V1 module.

VHDX format specs:
http://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=34750
